  407. For context, I'm a long-time Norelco electric shaver user--like 14 years--and they're all I really use. This one took me about 4-5 shaves before my face got used to it, which is surprising since I never need time to get used to other shavers (like when I've tried my dad's or my brother's). At first I thought I'd made a mistake in buying it because it was tad rough on my face and didn't get very close, but now I'm pretty happy with it. It doesn't get as close as most of the electric shavers I've used, but only by a small margin, and it gets close enough. I have a 5 o'clock shadow at like 2pm, but I don't mind and I still look clean enough for a professional business look. I sort of figured out how my face works best with it, like going a little slower, and it does a pretty good job. For the money, I feel like it's a pretty good deal. Fit and finish seems solid, and I especially was sold when I found out I could plug it in and use it immediately if the battery dies, unlike my old one that left me stranded. That was one feature my new shaver had to have. About the battery: I ran the charge it came with dead, then charged it overnight for 8 hrs. I used it every morning for at least 8 days and it just died on me for the first time (I plugged in a finished up). That's a really good battery, in my opinion.
  408. I'm really pleased with this shaver. Philips Norelco 7310. For the price it can't be beat.. recommend this shaver to anyone.
  409. I swore I'd never buy a Philips again, but here I am, using one at least once a week, after finding one over Christmas at a good price. While it works reasonably well, it has a few serious defects. The back cuts pretty well, though it can leave the skin a bit more sore than other heavy groomers. The main head, though, just can't seem to do a good job of totally removing already-trimmed, just-washed hair; no matter how many times I go over my skin I'll always find some hairs remaining, especially near the adam's apple or the nostrils. Whether my hair is dry or damp, it just can't seem to cut evenly. It does, however, do a much better job than my previous shaver, giving an extremely close shave that lasts for a couple of days (complete with some razor burn), which I would expect for the higher price... I just didn't realize it would only go from 60 to 90% coverage, not 100%.<br /><br />The shaver is very easy to maintain, and really hardly needs any maintenance except emptying. It would be nice if it showed you a battery level or even a warning as it's getting low when you first turn it on, but instead you just have to wait until it stops working and start charging.<br /><br />Edit: While the clippers in the back are still going strong, the blades on the head are soft and only seem to last 20 uses or so before starting to dull; over the next 40-50 uses it gets to the point where hardly anything is done at all, and it tends to grab instead of cut, leading to more burn and redness. I don't have particularly thick hair, maybe medium thickness, so you might get half or double depending on your hair.
  410. Amazon had a great deal on this shaver so I decided to give it a try. My first electric shaver (from many years ago) was a Norelco rotary head. I used it for many years before eventually switching to a straight blade razor to get a closer shave. I have somewhat sensitive skin so I get easily irritated if I use a straight razor every day. Hence, about 10 years ago I started using an electric shaver every other day and a regular straight razor with shaving cream on the days in between. (This eliminated the problems I was experiencing.) I have owned and tried many different electric razors over my 30+ years of shaving and have never encountered one that shaves as close as a straight razor with shaving cream. This makes sense if you think about it because with an electric razor there is always some kind of 'guard' between the blades and the skin. With a regular straight razor the blade is riding right on your skin. Anybody expecting an electric razor to shave as close as a blade is in for a disappointment -- and the Norelco 7310 is no different. Hence, I wasn't expecting a close shave, but I was pleasantly surprised at how good of a shave I did get! My beard is not very thick (medium density), but the hairs are very coarse and tough. I've only been using the 7310 for a few weeks now, but so far it hasn't been having any problems cutting through my hair. As mentioned previously, I have somewhat sensitive skin. And the one problem I did have with the 7310 -- and something I forgot when using my previous Norelco rotary head razor -- is that it gives me razor burn on my neck. (I don't get razor burn if I use a foil-type electric razor.) I then remembered a trick I learned with using my original Norelco: Always shave the neck are first and do not spend too much time on it. All things considered, I am very satisfied with this razor and think it performs excellent considering the purchase price.
  411. Ive been using this shaver for about four months. I had a Braun (foil) self-cleaning system, but got fed up with constantly buying the cartridges for it. I read reviews on various types and brands of razors and decided to try this one. This shaver blows my Braun away for many reasons! 1) No more buying cleaning cartridges that I had to replace appx. every 30 days @ $6 a pop (with the Philips/Norelco I simply push a tab to open the head and flush with warm tap water) 2) It is so quiet! 3) I have more space on the vanity because I no longer have that big cleaning/charging base that I had with my old shaver, now I can keep the razor in a drawer. 3) Recharging the battery is easy, once a week I plug it in to the charger and 2-3 hrs. later I'm good for another 7 days of cordless shaving. 4) For the price I paid for the Braun, I could've bought 3 or 4 of these (not that I would, so far it has been flawless). 5) Last, and most important, THE SHAVE IS GREAT!! I've been shaving for 40 plus years, tried many razors and this is by far the best. Very comforatable, no pulling sensation, very smooth feeling on the face and neck. I was very pleased after the first use. The shave was as close, if not closer, than a razor blade/lotion combo. Will not go back to anything else!!
  412. Bought this shaver on December 26 and worked really well until February 20 or so - when it would no longer charge and did not even work plugged in. Pretty good,huh. I knew when it arrived, it was cheap and probably reflects the price. But, really, a safety razor could last almost this long. Needless to say, disappointed. I remember with nostalgia the old ones that were heavy, made of metal, and lasted for years - probably made by union employees in New Jersey instead of slave labor in China ...........but those days are gone. Oh that's right - we don't have unions anymore. Ah, who needs em anyway.
  413. I purchased this razor for my husband January, 2011. I believed the Norelco name was good enough to not bother to check it out further. Boy was I mistaken. This razor has absolutely NO power even when used plugged in. Husband does not have a thick beard but he has to go over and over the same area so much EVERY TIME that he ends up with bad razor burn. We will be returning this product to the store and will NOT purchase another Norelco.
  414. Awesome just received this product yesterday, charged it up and used it today, it's quiet enough and it's a newer style than I have been using for the past 4 years ( a norelco reflex plus). Instead of buying replacement blades I upgraded to a sportier style and am looking forward to using this for years to come. Thanks Norelco and keep up the good work
  415. I have another Norelco for home & this one replaced an older travel shaver that had given up the ghost. It is just what I wanted. Price was right; sale and delivery were quick and efficient. Thanks!
  416. I'm giving it all she's got Captain!!! This is a nice starter razor, but it needs more power!!! It gives a nice clean shave(seems to work better wet), but it takes forever!!! I would recommend buying the more elite model and wish I had. PROS: cleans up easily, lightweight, works with or without cord, shaves wet or dry CONS: sluggish not enough power, takes forever to get a clean shave Recommend for someones first electric shaver, but suggest that you go to a better Norelco model!!!
  417. While this razor works well for 1-2 days worth of stubble, forget about it if you're on day 3 or more... the lack of power in this unit makes it only pull and pull, instead of spin and slice. Ouch!
  418. Yeah this is probably the best electric shaver under $50. I had an old Norelco that looks just like this one, and this is waaaay better. Not nearly as good as some of the Panasonic/Braun shavers that have the cleaning dock, but this is still way faster than shaving with a razor. College special.
  419. This is the 4th electric shaver that I have owned and the 2nd rotary type. I have owned the top of the line shaver from Panasonic, as well as mid-range units from Braun and Remington. The same thing has happened every time in the past. I give it two to three months and then I am back to a disposable razor that can shave closer, with less hassle, and less irritation. The number one reason each time for going back to a disposable was how the electric shaver failed to handle my neck hair. None of them seemed to be able to the job no matter what and then the hassle on the units I had that had an expensive cleaning unit made it a pain to use. Well I got the bug again to try an electric razor one more time and ended up purchasing this unit. And now after having it for a while I have to say that this is the best electric shaver that I have had. First and foremost it can handle my neck. It can't get it all in one pass, but the others couldn't do it no matter how many times I tried! Second, being able to just rinse the head under the sink is wonderful. No more cleaning systems that are bulky and expensive with the continual cost of the cleaning solution. Third, is that it is a surprisingly close shave. I kind of expected a 5 o'clock shadow by noon with a rotary shaver, but that isn't the case here. It is very close to a shave with a razor, NO KIDDING! It isn't the perfect electric razor, but it is more than worth the price. There are only two things that stick out with me that could have been done better and both are related to charging. First, it takes 8 hours to charge the unit from being almost dead, with no quick charge capabilities. You can get around it by just using it plugged in when you are in the middle of the charge. Second, is that there is no battery level indicator. It would be nice to have some sort of idea of how much of a charge you have left. In my book, these are just two minor issues that aren't that important to me, but keepme from giving it 5 stars. I have and will continue to recommend this unit to friends.
  420. I HAVE HAD THIS FOR OVER A MONTH & USE IT EVERY DAY....ITS THE BEST I'VE EVER HAD......THIS PHILLIPS/NORELCO ELECTRIC RAZOR IS THE BEST.
  421. I write this review for all men who are considering an electric razor but have not yet purchased one due to confusing and contradictory on line reviews. First the basics: Purchased from Amazon. As usual, excellent customer service. The razor comes in a blister pack that should include a warning label about how opening the package will result in severe finger cuts and massive blood loss. I have a light beard. I don't get a 5:00 shadow; mine is like a 2:30 shadow. I use electric razors 98% of the time, choosing a disposable only when I am too lazy to shave and I end up with a 5 day growth that is more easily tamed with a disposable. The Norelco 7310 is very different from the old rotary it replaces. The 7310 is feather light due to extensive use of plastics and it makes much less noise. No coiled cord; the recharging cable (like a cell phone charger) may be used to shave off AC if the battery has run down. After one week of use I am still using the razor off of the initial charge. My old Norelco could not do a good job on some \\"immature hairs\\" on my neck. After use, I usually used a straight razor to dispose of this growth. The 7310, much to my surprise, does a perfect job on the beard and the neck. I would say that my morning shave now takes less than two minutes. Hints: I always use Williams Lectric shave prior to shaving and I have to stretch my skin slightly to help the razor glide over the beard. The first two times I used the 7310 I felt some slight irritation on my neck after shaving. By the third day the irritation was gone. The manual states it takes some time for your face to adjust to the razor. They are correct. The 7310 comes with a two year warrantee. I suspect the unit will not last as long as my old one, but that seems to be true of all products today. For the price, this was an excellent purchase. I can't see how spending more money would get me a better shave. Go for it.
  422. Pros: Very close and comfortable shave Excellent sideburn trimmer Good battery life Charge completed flashing LED's Price is right if . . . Cons: No battery status indication, none expected Tacky colors I've been shaving for over forty years, mostly electric and mostly Norelco. For 3-months I had a Remington R450, see my review, huge dissapointment. Every couple of years Norelco tries to come up with a new gimmick to get us to purchase the latest and greatest. Thing is that Norelco got it right 30-years ago. The cutters and combs in the 7310 are the essence of that technology and if you can spin the cutters you'll have a close shave. All the other Whistles & Bells are just fluff. Norelco claims 10 days of cordless shaving on a 8-hour charge. The charge full indicator started flashing at 2-hours, done. I went 9-days and wondered how much longer, on the tenth day the motor started slowing down and it quit halfway through the eleventh day. By stretching the battery after the first charge/discharge I was able to get 12-days, well actually 11.9-days, could have used another minute of shaving. I stretch a NiCd by running the battery dead with the cutters flipped open for the lowest motor load. Pretty impressive for a single AA NiCd battery. People claim this is a good/great budget shaver. Nonsense, this is a excellent cordless shaver that can be had at a budget price. I got mine from the big W for thirty-one to my PO Box. It came in the full retail blister pack. By the time I got it to my house, 8500-feet, I thought it was going to explode. I saw at least two retailers have it for a bit less on Black Friday. Makes you wonder what the models that cost 4-5 times as much have to offer? So why is it ugly? Well of course beauty is in the eye of the beholder and this old eye doesn't do black and white on a shaver, all black . . sure, all white . . probably not, all silver like my deceased 7865XL's . . YES!!! I still gave the 7310 5-stars, I don't see the colors while shaving. BTW, I do like the white power switch. If you look at the photos I posted, you'll see that the 7310 consists of a small waterproof power module encased in four cosmetic shells. It's these shells that allow Norelco to play the silly color games at no additional cost. The sides even have rubber bonded to the shell. Turns out I shave with my thumb between the power switch and head and my fingers over the trimmer, so I don't even feel the \\"slip proof\\" rubber. Where are your fingers? So if the feature set meets your needs, don't hesitate to get the 7310, it will deliver a comfortable close shave. As to the colors, only you can decide.
  423. I should first say that for this price, what you get is a quite decent shaver. I am a big fan of the 7310 so far. It is more precise and comfortable than the 6xxx series.It is sold as 7320 in Europe to my knowledge as just \\"Philips\\" no Norelco, same exact features. CVS now has it for cheaper price, including 5ECB. Good things: 1. price 2. comfortable 3. efficient Things to improve: 1. It seems to work only after you charge it up. That means it takes 9 hours for a fully charge. 2. a little noisy when working 3. t doesn't shave the philtrum (nose-lip area) well By the way, it's 100-240V, so in any country you can use it.

  433. The battery in my Panasonic shaver would not keep a charge any longer. I had to toss it while I was in Nicaragua, but fortunately I had ordered this one before I left for my trip. It took about a week and a half to receive this using Amazon's free shipping. I wasn't sure if I would like a rotary since all I have ever used is the Panasonic/Braun type shavers with the single foil all of the way across the top. The verdict? This shaver works great for me. It gives me a very close shave and it is quiet with lots of torque. I believe the quietness is because of the load speed of the blades, but it still provides plenty of torque to cut those tough hairs without pulling them. This was a very good deal and I only give it 4 stars because it doesn't have any kind of battery status meter letting you know how much battery life you have left.

My parents always used Remington Shavers to shave my brother so after my parents passed away I kept buying Remington shavers. I did not like them too much but didn't think anything else was better. No matter how many times I went over the same section under his chin the hair did not come off. When I decided to buy a new shaver I read the reviews on this Norelco and when I read that it shaved the chin hairs I bought it right away. It's great - everything I hoped for.   437. Works good! I only wish that the head did not have to be replaced so often, at half the price of the whole razor.
  438. Strictly from a shaving performance point of view, this model performs as well as much more expensive Norelco shavers. I also own a Norelco 8175XL that costs 3 times as much and uses the blades advertised as having \\"50% more shaving area.\\" This shaves as fast, close, and comfortable as the more expensive shavers. If you've owned older Norelco shavers, you'll be pleased by advances such as a quiet motor, lithium ion (LiOn) batteries instead of nickel cadmium (NiCad), and the ability to clean the shaver by running it under the faucet. What it lacks is some indicator that the battery is running low. Some reviewers have commented on the fact that it takes 10 hours to recharge, whereas more expensive Norelco's rechage in 1 hour. I actually prefer the slower charge. The fast charge razors state that you should unplug the charger as soon as the charge is complete. I find it much more convenient to plug it in either overnight or when I go to sleep, then to remember to unplug it in an hour. Overall, a great value for the money.
  439. I bought it during last Christmas sale for $26 and extremely happy (for a price paid). I still use disposable Gillettes but only when I really need a cleanest shave and have time for that. Otherwise I use this one. True, it can leave some hair, especially on neck, but it's very convenient on the go, and I like to travel.
  440. I've used this razor for about a year now, and it's fantastic. As an Army man, I shave twice a day, keep my razor in my vehicle, and charge it once a week.   448. People suggest that the blades eventually get dull and need to be replaced. They don't. They just get clogged with hair. Push down on the yoke and remove all the blades. Remember how they came out. Use the included brush to get out all the hair that's wound around the drives. Takes about 20 minutes. Like new! No need to buy new blades!
  449. Have historically used Braun electirc razors but after reading the numerous reviews, and after 10 years of good use my Braun was packing up. Am disappointed with the Philips and wish I'd stuck to the standard foil and cutting system employed by other manufactures. Not only is it more manouverable (I find the Philips Shaver Head a bit bulky) but it provided a better shave and little if any irrititation. The Lift and Cut system of the Philips can be a little painful with the tugging, after a few days of growth. I never had this with the Braun. In addition, it shaves poorly in the neck area and gives quite a lot of irritation here. UPDATE I think that I was being a little kind to it at first, given that the instruction manual states that you should allow for a month for your skin to get used to it. The problem is, if you keep on using this product you won't have any skin left on your neck!!! I am not sure how this product is so highly rated, the other reviewers are right. To sum up: - extreme skin irritation especially the neck - weak motor - painful pulling Do not waste your money on this product. I am now left with a product which I do not use. Avoid at all costs!!
  450. Having been using this for the past few months, I figured it was time to review the product. I will break this down in a few areas that I find should be changed. Cons: <->The Speed on the razor when using the battery is slower than it should be, so You have to take your time to prevent some pulling of the hair. I usually shave every couple of days so you can see why I should be a bit faster or should have a way to speed it up for that really thick stubble that has grown. <->The weight of the shaver is really nice and fits just just right in my hand. I have in the past been really clumsy, so the bigger the better. I would like to see a way to check the battery level and so I don't charge the battery to early, Since you have so many charges for each battery this would extend the life of the battery by charging when it is needed. <->The Cover for the blades should cover more. The cover I have is just for the blades and should actually cover the entire front service including sides. I find that occasionally taken off the cover makes the shaved hair department open up and that can get annoying when your in a hurry. Now I know there are several cons but they are at least important in my mind. I do however have a couple pro's: <->The shaver gives a really close shave when I use it. <->The Sideburn cutter does a really good job when it comes to clipping the sideburns off. I haven't had any problem with that and it keeps me looking professional when it is needed. <->On a good battery, I have used this shaver off and on for several weeks without charging just would like to know the charge level before I charge it. <->I grew up with Norelco's and every time I use one I know it is a good shaver. I haven't had any major problems with my shaver and would recommend it for the money price. If your looking for a cheap shaver this is one of those that would suite you for the price and It is sturdy and dependable. I would recommendthis to my family and friends without reservations.
  451. I can't believe all these people are giving it 4-5 stars. I belive at least half of them are paid advertisers or are describing a different shaver. I bought the 7310XL for a mere $30 and I feel like I've been ripped off. People who paid $50 have been DEFINITELY ripped off. I'll start with what's good about this shaver: it can be washed, which is a great way to clean a shaver. But what does it matter when this thing does the worst job at shaving? The motor is the weakest I've ever seen. It feels like the motor in my 10-year-old philips when it runs out of juice, and it shaves like it has no power at all. I have to make multiple passes on every area until most of the hairs have been cut off. When I finish with this shaver, and my face is all red and hurting, I still have to use my razor or another, decent shaver, to finish the job as this shaver simply does not cut everything. I would definitely send it back if the store I bought it from took returns. Unfortunately, I'm stuck with a useless shaver that has a children's toy motor inside and I guess I'll have to keep looking (and maybe raise my budget).
  452. This Norelco budget shaver is a dream compared to some other higher-priced brands my elderly husband tried. As the directions and other reviewers stated, allow about three weeks to make the adjustment from safety razor to an electric shaver. Also, if you alternate between safety razors and electric shavers, there probably won't be a close shave with the electric shaver because the safety razor removes a thin layer of skin along with the facial hair. So, I am really going work on motivating my husband to use only the electric shaver on a daily basis. Electric shavers, regardless of brand, are not ideal for a close shave on hair growth of several days. So, if you are stuck with a shaver that needs to be replaced or one that you have never really thought gave a descent shave, try this Norelco model. It lacks all the bells and whistles and it is black and white, but it does what it is supposed to do if you follow the instructions and shaving tips enclosed. It was packaged well with all parts accounted for; it arrived super fast, and the price was right!

I figure getting this as a value shaver. You really do get what you pay for. The entire construction seems flimsy and plastic-ie. At least, my previous shaver had some metal parts and had some real weight to it. Anyhow, the shaving head speeds seem to be slower than usual, but for me, it gets the job done. The trimmer is comparable with my previous one. Finally, the water cleaning function is nice. I would recommend this as a backup or travel shaver and just spend more for a top of the line shaver.
  475. Purchased this Norelco for my husband as he was undergoing radiation and needed a gentle way to shave his face and neck area. We were both surprised at how well this little inexpensive shaver was. It did a great job on his neck and facial hair. He commented on how well it worked on those hairs that grow in different directions. I think he will continue to use this shavor even after his treatments are over. Very satisfied!
  476. This is my first Norelco shaver, and second electric shaver in my life--I've been a straight blade user I was a wee tad and decided to go electric these last few years. My first electric shaver was a Braun and I must say, proved very reliable and provided a semi-close shave (of course, not as close as a razor), and the only reason I needed a new one is because it would not power on anymore. As I've been using my new Norelco shaver for the past few months, I can only honestly say it's been a great investment. It definitely is provides a good shave, but one quib I have with it is that it misses hair strands on certain parts of my face that are not large enough for this to be a big issue, but are also not super small enough for me to ignore--as a result, I've found myself electric shaving first, then using my straight blade razor to shave off those missed pieces. I did not have this with my prior Braun shaver, and honestly this is the only fault of this razor. Overall: -Battery life: Amazing..I only charged it once as I am a fast shaver, because even when it loses life, the next day it still will power on for little under a minute (just enough for me to finish a quick shave)....this extended my need to charge my shaver too often. -Performance: Decent shave (with the exception of the quib noted in my first paragraph...misses certain hair strands on my face that require me to follow up with a straight blade razor -Convenience: Cord is not very long, but that's ok because I usually use it as a cordless anyway (however it can also be used corded if the battery isnt charged..i never use it this way though). -Ease of cleaning: It is very easy to clean! I typically just blow it out over the sink and tap the outside to knock all the remnants out throughout my week (it doesn't clean it perfectly but im usually in a rush to work). After 1-2 weeks I rinse it out with water cuz it can get gunked out..this takes a few minutes longer but makes it very clean. -Overall: Itis a decent shaver for a decent price...would recommend.
  477. My Norelco shaver arrived promptly and has worked well. It's the third Norelco I have owned, and in this case it was about as inexpensive to buy a new one as it would have been to buy replacement blades.
  478. I have been afraid of electric razors for many years, because they really irritate my neck. I picked this Norelco 7310 since it appeared to be flexible enough to cut the neck hairs without pulling. It was priced well .After obtaining it i read that it should be used a number of times before best shave. oh no! First couple of shaves seemed to pull a bit. Now after a week there seems to be no real pull and neck is not red and sore. Thanks

  483. Pretty good.This is the best shaver that I have used. I will buy another one for my dad. I strongly recommend this.
  484. This a comparatively inexpensive Norelco. I have one, and have given away three, very expensive Norelco razors. The one I kept is a Spectra model, and is the best electric I have ever owned. The 7310XL uses the same cutting head assembly as the Spectra, and it gives just as good a shave for less then a third of the price of the Spectra. I feel like I got a bargain. I would recommend this shaver, Philips Model 7310XL, to anyone who wants a good shaver for a good price.
  485. Strong note: If you shave every day, this razor will work reasonably well for you. If you let it go 2 or 3 days between shaves, shave ACROSS the direction of hair growth first. If you shave against or even with the hair it will catch and nick the skin relatively often. Shaving 90 degrees to growth will catch much less frequently, then once you've removed most of the hair shave against like normal to finish. Once you figure this out so it won't nick you so much after a couple days between, this is a relatively good shaver for the money.
  486. Been using it for a coupla weeks now. A very easy-to-use excellent shaver. Will update if need be over time to see how it fares. As of now, I highly recommend it for being sturdy and simple-to-use and care for.

He has been walking around the house just using it and its sooo funny..   489. I've long been a fan of electric razors, but in the past I've always been frustrated by how ineffective they are against the hair on my throat. This one, though, gave me a great close shave everywhere, including and especially on my throat. I've never really cared whether an electric gave me as close of a shave as a blade, but this is the first one I've ever had that actually did shave as close as a blade. One other cool thing is that this razor is VERY quiet. At first I thought there was something wrong with it (like it barely had enough charge to switch on), but given its performance, it's obvious that's the way it was meant to operate. Also, the top flips open (but stays attached) so that you can easily run the blades under a faucet to clean them. I've not tried more expensive electrics, but with how well this one works, I don't see any need to.
  490. Battery discharges very fast.<br />Not a razor (more like a trimmer).<br />Hurts the skin.<br />You need a twin blade razor with this razor/trimmer to complete the job.
  491. Pros: quiet motor, washable in water, close shave (eventually).<br />Cons: weak motor, long shaving time (5-6 minutes), not as close a shave as twin razor, too many plastic parts, no pouch for storage, short battery life<br />This could have been a good product if the motor is more powerful (like my 10 year old corded non-rechargeable Norelco shaver). I am disappointed with the new style of Norelco shavers. I am willing to try another brand.<br />10/25/2017 Update - This shaver still works with a very weak battery and short shaving time. However, it provides a closer shave than some of the newer Norelco rechargeable shavers. I found new Norelco's shavers are getting worse. I missed my old Norelco non-rechargeable corded shaver; it was powerful, consistent, and long life.
  492. I received this as a Christmas gift. I shaved with it once and was very pleased with the results. However, the second time i shaved with it something must have broken under the hood. Two of the three blades stopped spinning and the third (the lower of the three heads) began acting bizarre. Instead of having the blades spinning underneath the prtoective sheath mesh on top, the entire thing begun to spin (the mesh is usuallystationarywhilethe blade beneath it spins. This allows the blade to trim hairs that poke through the mesh. However, when the mesh is also spinning, this doesn't work and makes a terrible sound)<br />I'm very disappointed because I was really excited for the shaver after the first shave, now I have to return it and am currently debating whether to take another gamble with the shaver in hopes that it won't enchant the same issue, or to risk getting another, potentially worse shaver. Was it just a faulty product or is this shaver just not built to last ( more than one day.) disappointing, because people have very good things to say about it for it's price point.
  493. I have owned many Norelco's over the years. I normally try to buy them on sale. My wife takes my old one for her legs and I keep the new one. Over the years, I found how important it is to keep the same blade with the same foil. I mixed them up once and it ended up cutting the foil up and I was lucky it didn't do me damage. These things last years and many times it is cheaper to buy a new one than purchase a new set of cutting heads. Someone said it doesn't cut as close as a normal razor...well duh... Regular razors destroy my skin and I end up with in grown hairs. The only time I use a blade is when I have too long a growth to use my Norelco. The cut is great but not so close to distroy my face. This unit here is cordless and the blades turn a bit slow for my taste. Maybe that is why the fire sale on this model. For the price, the blades are worth it as a replacement for a suitable Nerelco, even if you don't like this razor. I would take this model over any other brand even with the slower speed. It's a Norelco but I would have to put it towards the bottom of all the units I have owned.

I did both and as a result didnt even waste a stamp trying to get the rebate.<br /><br />That said, amazon should have made it more clear the rebate wouldnt stack with the offer.   510. I've been using blades for the last 10 years. But the cost of the fancy blade packs has been creeping up and up until it has become less expensive to buy an electric razor than to buy the replacement blade packs. (Amazon Gillette Manual Cartridge, Fusion, 12-Count - $29.25, this electric shaver $39.77.) Which works out to $10 more for the first year, but I expect the Norelco to last much longer than 1 year. I bought an inexpensive mode because I wasn't sure I'd like it. It has worked great right out of the box. It does take a little getting used to and my skin needed to adjust the new way of shaving. Blades still give me a little closer shave, and they glide across my face easier, BUT the convenience of just grabbing the Norelco and shaving, without the need of a sink and running water outweighs the difference. If I'm running late, grabbing the Norleco on the way to the car and shaving on the fly is great. It's just quicker from start to finish. And if you travel where the water quality, purity and safety are suspect, the Norelco offers and additional advantage in not needing bottled water to shave (to be safe). I gave it 4 stars because it needs a battery gauge, what you see in the picture under the word charge is just that an indicator. You plug the unit and the charge light comes on, it stays on solid green until the unit is charged and then it flashes green. But once you unplug it you never see the indicator again until you charge it again (about weekly). The obvious problem is that you never know the amount of charge left in the battery. At home this isn't a big problem as you can plug it in and shave with it while it is plugged in. However grabbing it on the way out the door and jumping in the car is less reliable. My solution is to charge the battery every Monday morning, so it hasn't been a problem for me yet. Yes I can recommend this shaver, and when the time comes I might just get a little better model (based on the shaving heads used in the model). I'm not complaining about the heads in this unit, but looking at the different replacement blades from Norelco I can see that some of the other ones have more slots for shaving. I'm not sure it will make any difference, but I'd be willing to give it a try.
  511.   512. this was my first purchase and use of an electric razor. i purposely bought this unit because of the Norelco name (i've been pleased with their beard trimmers for years), and the great price ($25). i've always shaved with a razor, most consistently a Mach 3, but they always left bumps on my neck if i shaved more often than every other day. so i thought i'd give electric razors a try, and this one seemed to be a good entry level unit without much investment if it didn't work out. i've been pleasantly surprised. i've shaved with it daily since christmas, and the red bumps and irritation are gone! it's cordless, which is very practical, and i've only charged it twice in nearly one month of use. it's very easy to clean since the head pops right open and it can be rinsed in the sink. since i don't have any experience with other electric razors, i can't compare the shave quality to anything but a regular razor. and since my wife hasn't complained, it must me leaving me at least as clean shaven or more so than the Mach 3.

I was able to quickly shave with minor razor burn, compared to other models that have I used in the past.   518. It's very quiet, Shaves smooth and close and it's easy to clean. Better than the more expensive units that self clean in a solvent solution, you just pop open the hinged head, rinse with hot running water, close it, shake water off, open it back up and let it dry. Takes about as long as it takes to read above sentence. It's got a trimmer that works. The battery last long enough for a week of motel hopping and if it fails in the middle of a shave just plug it in and keep going. A battery charge indicator would have been nice but it's really not essential. Since I got more than I expected for $40 I've got to give it 5 stars.<br /><br />I bought this on a friend's advice after my expensive Braun had been broken. The Braun was quicker but both deliver a very smooth shave with the edge to the Braun, however the slight difference is not worth seven times the price.<br /><br />EDIT: Just noticed that they're trying to sell this for $100. You have to rely on being able to hear that motor slowing down. A couple of times I've been shaving, turned it off for a few seconds during a shave and it wouldn't turn back on because it had no charge.<br /><br />Overall though, this is a good budget razor that provides a good shave.

  540. I wish I had bought a vacuum cleaner instead...at least I would expect it to suck. As of this review, this product has 837 reviews: 437 five-star, 238 four-star, 78 three-star, 40 two-star, and 44 one-star. With ratings like that, I thought this would be a great-value and a decent razor at a good price. I did my research and I was still wrong. My only complaint about this razor is that it does not cut well. I have used electric razors for 20-plus years and this one is the worst I have purchased. I had a Norelco in college and thought it did a decent job, but have been using Braun foil-type razors for the last 10 years or so (mostly because of value/performance). This razor does such a poor job that I use a [[ASIN:B002TQ4AO0 Braun M90 Mobile Shaver, Silver, 1]] to \\"clean up\\" what this razor misses. I bought the M90 for a camping razor or a backup...right now it is my primary razor. I have also owned the [[ASIN:B001FA1F8K Braun Series 1 1-150 Men's Shaver]] and the [[ASIN:B003YJB026 Braun Series 5-550cc Shaver System, Black and Silver]] (it was a gift). While I am not doing a review for those particular razors, they both cut closer than this one. I don't have a very coarse beard and it takes me two days to get a five o'clock shadow. The razor does not irritate my skin (probably because I have always used electric razors). I have spent 10 minutes or more trying to get a closer shave only to finish up with my M90 in 1-2 minutes. I have shaved with this thing for 30-days and see no improvement in my face \\"getting used to it\\" nor in the cutting performance. As for the other 1-star reviewers, I don't have any issues with battery life, motor speed, hair pulling, cleaning, skin rashes, or poor quality workmanship. If the thing would cut the hair on my face, maybe I would quibble about such things. Since it does not cut, my recommendation is to keep looking. Don't trust the reviewers for this one...you'll end up regretting that you bought this thing.
  541. I bought this shaver for about 44 dollars and I believe it was a good deal. I had a previous 50 dollar Panasonic that cut just as good, but did not have a rechargeable battery and it was also not cordless. The battery life does last about thirty minutes but if you take longer than that you might not be doing something right. Anyway, it cuts great but not as close as a blade. If you take extra time you can get it pretty close though. It wont pull your hair if you're used to electric razors and have not noticed any thing that makes me not want to shave with it. I actually prefer to use it more than blades because it definitely saves me a lot of time and I dont have to be as careful. The side burn trimmer works good but not as good as clippers. It cleans very very easy under running water, after that you just let it dry and plug it in to charge. It lets you know when it's fully charged and make sure to not overcharge the unit so that you get the best battery life. For the price range, it does what you may expect.
  542. After using Norelco's for 25+ years now I would have to say: 1. this is the closest shave I've ever got from one and 2. in todays money this is the most inexpensive Norelco I've ever purchased.
  543. Cuts very different then my old Remington shaver, so use caution on sensitive areas. Otherwise its a very simple unit that seems to cut fairly well.
  544. I have been shaving for aprox. 30 years, and no matter the price, or brand, always had some hair's left behind ( i have thikh hair ) Not anymore!+ It held the charge for 2 months, not kidding! I only shave every other day, i charged it on dec. 8th, after buying it, and are now, for the first time, charging it again, feb. 11th 2012. WOW! Not bad for a 27$ shaver from Wallmart. This is model# 7310XL, doen't know if the XL makes a differens on the battery? but i am very pleased!
  545. This is my third Norelco shaver. I bought the first on around 2000 for $100+, the second came from Amazon in 2006. Both succumbed to the same issue - battery age. The NIMH battery battery pack Norelco uses is good for about 5 years, after which it pretty much stops taking charge. Replacing it would be a snap, it is really just to AA rechargeables, if Norelco did not solder the battery pack, so if you want to keep your shaver, you either have to service it (expensive!) or learn to use soldering iron. My solution, then and now was to replace the entire shaver. It particularly makes sense with this one - it is cheaper than the pack of the replacement heads!<br />So, the positives: it is cheap. Really, I paid $28 for it, and a set of HQ6 heads for my old shaver is 30. It makes not sense at all but nevertheless that's how Philips pricing works. It looks and feels good, in my opinion black and white scheme makes it sleek and modern. It shaves well, it is just as good any other Norelco shaver - if you used one before, and liked it you won't be disappointed. The charger slot is the same as on older models.<br />Now, the negatives, all minor things, really. First of all, I really miss LCD screen of my old shaver which showed the remaining charge. I thought I would and I do, so if this is something you find very useful this may not be a shaver for you. Looks are cool, but a rubbery grip is an absolute magnet for hair. The charger connection is not 100% reliable, after the first few times it lost connection from being moved during charging I learned to double-check. There's no travel bag. Not really a negative, but it is 1.5 oz lighter than my old shaver and felt sounded like a cheap plastic toy a few first times, before I got used to it.<br />So, in the end - do I regret buying it? Not for a second! But 5 years from now, assuming I still can afford electricity, I may go for a more upscale model.
  546. Title says it all, but new seperated pivoting heads are adjustment but nice. Great buy for name and quality!
  547. I have owned this shaver for 2 years. Norelco makes shavers that are durable and easy to use. Unfortunately, I have to shop for one that will give me a closer shave (with less work). Even with repetive shaving of the same areas, this razor will not give a close shave.

  549. this shaver may be good for little boys no good for real beard. i hate it going to get new blades for my 7775 and go with it until it don't go no more. philips norelco 7310 xl
  550. works great, and comes with a shaver for nose and ear hair
  551. Received mine about three weeks ago. Even though the manual included recommends giving it three weeks for your skin to adjust, my skin adjusted very quickly and the unit produced excellent results from day one. The battery life is surprisingly good: a single charge lasted long enough for daily shaves of 2-3 minutes for almost two weeks. The charge-full indicator is also good: the flashing reliably lets me know when to unplug the unit. The sideburn trimmer is nothing special but works OK. Cleaning the unit is nice and easy (just hold it under a running hot tap). The quality of the shave itself is easily en par with shaving using an ordinary safety razor, if not a little better because it's more consistent. It also copes better than a safety razor does with coarse hair e.g. on one's neck. Other reviewers have described feeling that the machine is pulling out their hairs rather than cutting them: this hasn't been the case for me. It hasn't been painful at all shaving daily. I *did* however notice what they describe if I let my beard become too long - more than, say, 2mm - before using the unit. (This happens mostly around the tip of the sideburns.) So: 1. Use the sideburn trimmer to avoid longish hairs before using the shaver proper. 2. If your beard is longer than a couple of millimetres, shave using something else first? I haven't experimented properly to find out what's best to do in that situation, yet. This machine has made shaving much, much more pleasant for me, to the extent that daily shaving is now part of my routine (previously, it was too much effort). If and when this unit wears out (no sign of that yet!) I'll be buying this brand again.
  552. Good price and quanlity. Made in China.......... Easy to use. Plastic outside. I give is as a gift to my grandfather. He likes it.
  553. When shopping for a shaver to replace my 20+ year old Norelco, I only looked at Norelco. When I saw the prices for the top of the line model, I was amazed. Then I saw the 7310XL at a more reasonable price. I had some doubts about how good a shave I would get with a less expensive shaver but figured it would give me at least as good a shave as the old Norelco that I was retiring. The new 7310XL turned out to be better than I expected. It shaves much closer then the old one ever did and is so quiet, I can't tell if its running without putting it right up to my ear. Of course part of that is becase I am 84 now and my hearing stinks. I have noticed pretty skimpily clad girls being attrackted to my smoooth skin but my dog is happy to lick my face now that it is so smooth. Buy it now at Amazon. It also holds a charge for at least a month. budgottesman.com
  554. The shaver is good, the power is just so so, and curvature is not very good, not very clean after shaving!
  555. I bought this cause I got it pretty cheap. Else I had read about electric shavers not being so good etc. I was actually quite surprised with this one. It provides very smooth shave and quite easy to use. Just used it two times and I already feel comfortable with it. Best use will be for traveling etc. There are few drawbacks but that could be common to all electric shavers. Because of repetitious moves over the same spot, I feel a bit of more irritation, compared to regular razor. I usually shave once in a week and best use I found for this shaver was..... use it first with quick easy strokes going easy on skin and then finish off with regular razor in one pass. That way, I get least skin burn. Overall, I am happy that I bought this, highly recommended.

The sluggishness is what makes #1 above. 3) It misses hairs sporadically. So I have like 10 random hairs that it never catches.   568. This is my 3rd shaver from Norelco. The first one was 6400 which lasted more than 4 years.   583. I bought this product based on the reviews here at Amazon and am happy with my purchase. I particularly appreciate the many reviewers who have had several other electric shavers at various price points and stressed that in terms of just the shave, this Norelco was on par with top of the line shavers that cost $100+ more.<br /><br />This is my first electric shaver, so I cannot provide such comparisons. I would, though, like to point out a few things that I didn't see in previous reviews that might help others make a decision. First, although this is an electric shaver and cannot possibly provide as close of a shave as the ones that use razor blades, I was impressed at just how close the shave is with the 7310XL. As is pointed out in the instruction booklet, which I guess many people ignore, it helps if you stretch your skin with your non-shaving hand. Also, make sure your skin is dry and be sure to shave against the grain. Finally, don't press too hard or it may pinch your skin (another tip of the instruction manual). Using this four-pronged technique, I am able to get an impressively smooth shave.<br /><br />My biggest concern was shaving around my jaw bone (I'm quite skinny so don't have the benefit of a nice round jaw line). While this does take longer to shave than the rest of my face combined, I was able to get a satisfactory shave here too. Lastly, I have sensitive skin, so was worried about irritation; several reviewers mentioned that this was an issue for them. I actually found the irritation to be mild (no worse for me than with a blade-based razor). And, by just splashing a little warm water on my face I was able to alleviate the little itchiness that I did feel. Note: the instructions also point out that irritation is common in the beginning and should subside within the first 21 days of exclusive use.<br /><br />I hope this helps. Happy shaving!
  584. Philips Norelco 7310XL Men's Shaving System very good . i like this product! my father like too . i will keep ~

It's noisier but the quality of the cut is good enough for me and I like the popup trimmer.<br /><br />I don't think the higher end models are worth the additional expense because the cutters all wear over time and have to be replaced. I'm pretty cheap and when it's cheaper to replace a shaver than the cutters then that's what I'll do. I went with 4 stars because it's very light in weight and doesn't feel well made but does a nice job on my face without having to go over an area several times.

Update: I've now owned it for a couple of months. The second charge lasted over a month. The shave seems less impressive on second thought. OK but nothing outstanding.
  615. I'm a budget shopper and a budget shaver. This is the nicest, easiest, closest shaving, least abrasive shaver I've owned. The ability to wash the blades out under running water is fantastic. This shaver is top of the line for the low end price range.
  616. It's very functional. I bought two during Thanksgiving. It's a great deal with $10 mail-in-rebate. My husband and my father in-law love this shaver very much.
  617. Ordered this for my husband. He absolutely loves this thing. Says it is quieter than any razor he has used & gives him the smoothest,fastest shave he has ever had compared with other razors he has owned.
  618. I've had more expensive shavers with more blade holes but they have smaller slots. This one just has one row of blades on each of the 3 blade rings, but to me the whisker slots are slightly bigger and handle all face areas with ease. I've tossed my much more expensive Norelco with all the bells and whistles. I even bought this one on sale for less than replacement blades for the other one.
  619. Since high school, I have owned corded and cordless shavers from almost all the major brands. In my humble opinion, the Norelco and Panasonic are the two best. It comes down to whether you like a foil or a rotary head style. Personally,I found this as great rotary dollar for dollar. I had a clipless coupon here on Amazon and there was an amazing price before the coupon. The shaver was less than $20. On price alone, it's a 5 star deal. But price isn't everything. I like the durability, and Philips uses cheaper plastic than my shavers from the late 1990's early 2000's . The charging cord is also flimsy. They do score major points with the ability to rinse the heads under water. So for an entry or slightly above entry level, you won't be disappointed. If you like more meat on the bone, go up a few models.
  620. I wanted an electric razor that would work with or without being plugged in. I've let it go several days on one charge and it finally quit today, but after plugging it in for a few seconds I was able to finish shaving with it plugged in. You can open the top and run it under the faucet to clean it out, which is a nice feature. The back has the sideburn/mustache trimmer which works well. Overall I'm quite satisfied with everything so far.
  621. This is the least expensive in the line for norelco. I had a 10.00 coupon, so the total price was just over 20.00 plus shipping. It is great as a backup shaver. Don't know if that is even possible anymore. Low quality made in China seems to be the new normal. Oh, and one more thing. What the heck is this I read about your face may take a few weeks to get used to the razor? In the forty years I've used Norelco rotary razors, have never heard this before. Apparently new razor irritates your face until you &#34;get used to it&#34;. What if you have been using similar razor for years? Do you still need a break-in period? This sounds crazy to me.   639. I have always had a heavy beard, so I was never the ideal Norelco user, even 'way back when. But after avoiding Norelco shavers for approximately 35 years, I thought to be fair, they probably deserved another chance. My experiences with them back in the early-to-mid 1970s weren't very good, but a lot has happened since then, and I thought they were probably much better by now, even though they still look a lot like they did. They're lighter, because they're mostly plastic now, where they used to be mostly metal. They're a bit better designed, and a bit easier to clean. But the same old deal-breaking problem is still there: a long, slow shave - not a good thing for sensitive skin, or a guy in a hurry - and never a very close shave. I guess I'm hopelessly spoiled at this point, because nothing will do anymore but a nice foil screen, like Panasonic or Braun, and preferably a single cutter - not two, not three. With them, you can put the power where you want it, not wherever it wants to go. Faster, closer, better. I used this shaver for less than a month, and have since bought another Braun. And not a moment too soon.

  648. It's been a long time since I last used an electric shaver. This one impressed me as I get a close shave comperable to the one I was getting with the Mach 3 Turbo manual razor minus the shaving cream and replacement blades. The battery life is amazing. It took much less time than is specified for it to charge(it's at full once the green charge light starts blinking), and I've been using it while watching the morning news. I don't use it every day as every 2 or 3 is enough for how fast my facial hair grows, but I still haven't had to recharge it in over a month of use. Maybe some people have faces that are tougher to shave or are obessive about trying to get every last bit of facial hair(I have a couple spots that I get good enough since I don't feel it's worth an extra 10 minutes to make them perfect.) Cleaning is easy, though you do need to shake it to get some of the hair out of the top. I would reccomend this one over the more expensive counterpart as that one is only getting a bit fussy, and the design doesn't look as nice as this one.

  650. I've been a Norelco fan for a very long time and have owned 3 in the past. So when it came time to buy a new one, I looked through many reviews for the SensoTouch and tried to think of when I should spend $200 on a razor. It has all the bells and whistles, but the thing that really turned me off was the elevated design, which requires you to take the head off to clean it. I really like opening it up, washing it, then leaving it on the counter to dry. So I look at this model, and it looks quite similar to the ones I've used in the past, and $30 seemed like a great bargain. I've never tried to buy replacement blades but I heard this is a similar price, so I couldn't really go wrong. When I got it, it was exactly as I imagined. It doesn't feel like you're holding $200, but it is nice and actually quite light. It's actually quieter than my previous model as well. It worked very well and didn't pull painfully. It doesn't sound as strong as my previous either but I think that's more developing technology than loss in power, because the shave was clean. All in all I'm extremely happy with the purchase and figure I can use this for 2-3 more years before even thinking about replacing it. For me, this is the true value of Norelco, not the 3 dimensional, power gauging, self-cleaning one. I even thought about buying another one just in case it's not $30 in 2-3 years, but I know from experience that letting a battery go unused that long is not good.

  674. Weak. If you have wiry whiskers and more than one days growth, it's torture when running (pulls rather than cuts) and will stall out easily.
  675. ****Please note that I decided to tighten and revise this review, as I have had this razor for several years. I would now give it 4 stars for quality, 5 stars for value. My initial opinion was too negative. This shaver provides a fairly standard Norelco (i.e. 3 head rotary shaver) shave. This is my third Norelco (well second, but I bought a third one recently), and by far the lowest priced one I've owned. If you like the Norelco shave, I think this is an excellent value. Of course, many prefer the Braun/Phillips type single head razors, but it seems there is no way to tell who will prefer which. If you have never tried a Norelco, this would be a good model to try because of the low price. I now have an 8345 (which is the same as the 8340 but comes with extra heads) in addition to this one. The 8345 may be more money and newer, but they look, feel and shave fairly similarly. 8345 has more holes on the heads (can only be good I guess) but the motor sounds like it runs a lot slower. They seem to shave about as well, but the cheaper 7310 actually seems a bit gentler on the face (maybe because the 8345 has more holes but runs slower). The 7310 feels generally solid enough and comfortable in the hand. Feels like all the Norelco's do, more or less. The pop up trimmer seems reasonably solid, and functions like all of these pop-up trimmers do. It will shave your sideburns, but you may or may not be satisfied with it. Nature of the beast. The plug is also a little on the large side, which could be an issue for traveling, though not that bad really. I dont think it came with a travel case, but I could have misplaced it. The battery cannot be changed easily because its welded in. At $40-50 for the razor, I suppose that is not a huge issue, but its not a plus factor either. I think this is true of all Norelcos. This razor does hold a charge for quite a while, its good for several shaves without a recharge. However, there is no charge indicator at all. There is a green light that comes on when the razor is on, and another green light when its plugged in, but nothing changes as the battery gets low that I can see. You know it needs a charge when the motor starts to slow. A 5 or 10 minute emmergency charge is fine, so its not a great problem. About the only difference between this razor and the $100+ Norelco I used to own was that the expensive one had a battery charge indicator. Maybe there was more metal and less plastic in the more expensive one, but...so what? I have had this razor for 2 1/2 years, and use it about every other day. Maybe the battery doesnt last as long and the heads are duller, but its nothing I notice. I have put 0 money in it, and it still works well and compares well to my other electric razors. Verdict: good shaver if you like Norelco's, and a bargain at $40-50. Spending more money is recommended if you want a batter charge indicator, but beyond that, not clear to me what you get for your extra money. If you like the Braun-type razors better, I dont know of any reason why this one would convert you, but I can otherwise recommend this razor pretty strongly.
  676. This is my third electric after having two mid-priced Remington shavers. Decent shave and comfortable, the trimmer on the back doesn't seem to cut as close as my previous razors, and unlike the Remington's which flip the trimmer in and out with one switch this razor pops the trimmer out with a switch then you have to push it back in. Not that that's really a big deal.<br /><br />The one weird thing about it is it has two bright green LED's on the front which are steady when it's charging and then blink furiously once it's charged. The majority of the time it just sits plugged in in the bathroom, so it's usually charged and flashing away. Really it makes more sense to me to have it flash while charging then steady when it's done. Anyway if you don't mind waking up to go in the middle of the night and having your bathroom strobing green like a rave party then it's a good shaver.

  689. After using a series of Braun shavers for 20 years, I decided to see how the Norelco would work out. My first reaction was that it was so light and plastic, it felt like a toy. However, after a month of use I can say this low cost alternative stacks up pretty well. I am satisfied with the performance, let's just hope the unit lasts. It is also markedly quieter than my previous Braun. I've had no problem transitioning to the rotary head. Good value for the money so far...
  690. I bought this shaver to replace one that I have had for several years that is the same model . I replaced it because the blades had gotten dull . When I shopped for replacement blades online I found that there as an option of replacement blades or an atachment which sharpens the existing blades . Each of these cost about half the price of a new shaver . I concluded that given the age of my shaver the best thing to do was to purchase a new shaver . I hoped that the latest model would be better in some way than the older one , which seems to be true . The trimmer of the older model seemed to not work as well as some shavers I had owned previously . The new one seems better . Also the speed, even when fully charged of the older shaver seemed to me to be a little slow even when it was new . The new shaver does seem to rotate faster. So all things considered I think this shaver works well and is priced fairly among its competitors . And I am enjoying not having to work so hard shaving with dull blades !
  691. I haven't used an electic razor since I first started shaving regularly and my dad got me one. I switched to non-electric when I got on my own. I recently decided that an electric shaver would be a good Father's Day present for my kids to get me. I checked the ratings on Consumer Reports and this one was best bang for the buck there. I didn't have ANY trouble switching. No 3 week period of rashes or ingrown hair though I am having some slight redness on parts of my neck that goes away quickly. The sideburn trimmer works very well to shorten things up for shaving when I let it go for a few days. This thing is GREAT.
  692. i have been through many shavers in my time.with kind of a tough beard, i usually go 6 months till my electric needs new blades.last couple have been remington's, but this norelco is one of the best shavers i have ever had!absolutely cant beat it for the price.i almost ordered another one just to have it when this one wears out.still sharp after 4 or 5 months, and my neck hair is tough as nails.
  693. I had my last electric razor for many years, but slowly it lost its ability to serve. My shave was not as close and the hair on my neck remained untouched. To clean up my face I switched to a manual razor for awhile. Father's day changed things. I received this Philips Norelco 7310XL as an early Father's day gift.<br /><br />I like several things about this shaver.<br />It provides a close shave<br />It shaves the hair on my neck.<br />It does not hurt my skin.<br />It is fully washable - my last one was a pain to keep clean.<br />It has a two year warranty<br /><br />Maybe the best feature is the very close shave I get with this product. This razor is almost as good as a razor blade for providing a close shave. I tried alternating between the razor blade and the electric razor and it is tough to tell the difference.   694. This shaver is better than I expected!! I shave my head and my beard with it, use it to trim my stash also@ I would HIGHLY recommend this for the price!
  695. This is a pretty decent shaver, and you've probably read all about it in the other reviews, so I'll take about my one gripe: This does not give a very close shave. You'll have to do 2-3 run throughs to achieve the baby-smoothness a manual razor will give you the first time through. The smaller, pop-out shaver on the back of this thing is great for manscaping, but the main three-head shaver isn't very good. I switched back to manual razors for shaving my face, especially after I saw skin under a microscope that had been shaved with manual and electric razors. The manual razors left a nice, even pattern, but the electric shavers left the skin dry and irritated, and created unevenness in the pattern of new hair growth. That aside, this is really convenient for quick dry shaves, but I'd stick to a manual razor or go for a higher quality electric shaver if I were you.
  696. I'm a shaving cream and razor kind of guy and I am not picky about razors. I actually like using cheap disposable razors that are 'worn' because I have sensitive skin. This Philips shaver kind of irritates my skin but for the shave, it is not bad if you are in a hurry. Although this is probably not a big problem since all new razors and shavers irritates your skin. The thing that irritates me about this shaver is its packaging and certainly not one of those 'frustration free' packaging.   722. I have an old (only in years) Norelco 4853XL that I got when I was a teenager in high school. It has been over 10 years and that still works but I wanted to see what technology has done since then. The 4853XL is very similar to the 7310XL with most of the same features and I usually use it plugged into the wall now since the rechargeable battery doesn't work so well and the blades aren't as sharp as they used to be.<br /><br />The 7310XL is awesome. Improved grip and design. The blades are able to cut I would say about 10% closer than the 4853XL. When it comes to hair, that is pretty good. The side burn trimmer has been improved. What I notice is that it is not as loud as the 4853XL. Not sure if that is because the rotary blades are spinning slower or if they don't need to spin as fast as before because of improved design. I like how you can wash the blades even though you could on the old model by just removing the compartment and hitting it on the sink to get the hair out and then spraying water through the blades. Not sure if the 4853XL was designed for that but it still works after over 10 years.<br /><br />Bottom line: the 7310XL is probably the best men's face shaver you can buy. It is better than the more expensive ones because you aren't getting much improvement at the higher price. It is also definitely not one of the cheaper brands. I was able to get it for under $30 and hopefully it last just as long as the 4853XL - which still runs great even today.

  738. I've used the same Norelco shaver for the last 15 years or so. I don't clean it as often as I should and am sure I have not followed the manufacturer's instructions for maintenance very well. That being said, the thing still works pretty well and the only reason I decided it was time for a new one was that the battery has started to go and doesn't hold a charge very long. I've had a couple other razors over time(both gifts) of the micro screen type. On one of them the screen wore out fairly quickly and the other just didn't shave close or efficiently enough and pulled whiskers enough to cause slight pain. I knew that a screen shaver was not for me, and I've had good experience with Norelco, which lead me to this shaver. I read many reviews on the 7310 and other similar items and settled on this one mostly due to the good reviews and cost. At the time there was an online coupon for $10, bringing the price down to $20. I was a bit disappointed when I powered it on (after full charge) and could barely hear the motor. I have a thick beard so I was hoping that a new shaver would have some noise to it, and I suppose my assumption was that the louder, the more powerful. I have to say that although the motor does sound weak, it shaves surprisingly well and close. In fact, I normally use a combo of electric and razor - electric to go around some bumps and then a traditional razor for that extra close shave. During the first couple weeks, the shave has been so close that I couldn't justify breaking out the shaving cream and razor, it just wasn't necessary. I also like the fact that the heads are waterproof and can be cleaned under a faucet. I've been using the razor for two weeks and so far am very pleased. I give it 4 stars only because I reserve 5 stars for items that completely blow me away beyond my expectations. This item didn't knock my socks off, but it is a great value for the money and I highly recommend it.
  739. Norelco is a good standard name brand for Electric Razors. 40 years ago I owned an Electric shaver by Norelco. Since trying this one, (because I have usually been discouraged by them) the technology has finally advanced with this new design, new materials and new cutting technology. I recommend it but pay attention to the battery charging method. Also I recommend in the electronics section for (dry air in a spray can used to blow dust away in electrical contacts and PCB's) to quickly clean dust away, easier to clean that way for me.

  747. I ordered the Philips Norelco 7310 electric razor when I first got to Afghanistan. I was expecting being out here it would take a long time to ship, but it got to me surprisingly fast (about 12 days from the states, to Okinawa and finally to Afghanistan.) It came fully charged and packaging completely intact. It's great for anyone in the military to have, especially those who spend a lot of time outside the wire where there is no running water to use a regular razor to shave with.<br /><br />Now to talk about the razor its self.... Good quality in general. The motor is a little slow for my liking, but the heads are sharp as can be so it still cuts really smooth, really fast. The trimmers are kind of chintsy and don't do the best job at trimming or lining up which is the reason for the 4 star instead of 5. I'm also not a huge fan of the cheap plastic cover that guards the cutting heads. It never wants to stay on when I'm not using it. Fixing the problem was as simple as adding some electrical tape to give it a little tighter hold. Charge time - AWESOME for how long it can be used. You can shave every day for 3 weeks and only have to throw it on the charger for 3-4 hours and it's back to full charge.<br /><br />Would deff recommend to anyone. For the price, you can't beat it and the shave you get from it and the awesome battery life is that or better than some of the $100+ electric razors out there.

  749. I have bought this shaver on Thanksgiving because price looked good with 10$ rebate. When I got it, it did not look good but I thought that for the price with rebate it is ok,<br />but without rebate I would return it. So I sent rebate. After more than 4 month I received standard card with response that manufacture's discounts taken at the cash register are not valid for rebate promotion. In condition of rebate there was no such restriction, they only referred specifically to some 5$ instant rebate offer, and vaguely stating that such rebate offers are not eligible, but there was no 5$ rebate on Amazon. I called Philips and they told me that products bought for even little discounted price anywhere (in Walmart, Target, on Amazon, any other internet or B&M retailer) are not eligible for rebate. So it looks like circulating rebate offer was ploy to entice buyer to buy product and not able to return it after long period of waiting for rebate and with cut UPC code. It seems to be true looking at number of people hoping to get rebate and at complaints of not getting it in reviews.

  760. I've owned the Norelco electric razor for 2 years and have finally decided to try and find something that can provide a close shave and not painfully pull the hairs out of my face rather than cut them. This was my first electric razor (and I'm over 60). At first I was enamored with the novelty. It did give a close shave if you spent enough time going back over your face (and grinding it in to get it close). And it was ok as long as I didn't let my beard grow out for more then 2 days. With a 3-day growth it pulled the hairs and was quite painful. It's gotten less effective over time and in fairness there is recommended maintenance to reposition the cutters periodically, which I haven't done. Also has a good battery life. It was also much less expensive when I bought it 2 years ago ($39).

  762. I received this as a replacement to a defective 7110 and was reasonably impressed with the performance after charging it overnight. The battery and motor weren't up to the challenge of a one-day beard after only 3 uses. That's not good enough for me - it's back in the box and heading back to Phillips along with the 7110.
  763. I recently replaced my Panasonic ES8097A with this model, which is about half the price of the Panasonic. This Philips model is quieter than all linear blade razors that I've used. The first charge on the battery actually lasted 23 days for me, although I'm a pretty easy shave. The battery dies suddenly and then you can plug it in to finish a shave (with full power to it). The shave is close enough that I no longer do a manual shave once a week and this model does a great job on my neck compared to previous linear blade systems as well. For ~$45, this is a great deal so far.
  764. I hope it lasts as long as the Norelco shaver I had purchased in 1980! This one is smooth as silk...and quiet as a mouse
  765. My husband was very happy with this shaver. Said it was in some ways better then the more expensive one.
  766. Superb product. I have both the Philips Norelco 7310 and the 7340 - at different homes. Both are high quality products. I have had no issues. Over a long period of time. The only difference between the 7310 and the 7340 is the three circular cutting heads. The 7310 has straight slots for cutting while the 7340 has straight slots and tiny holes. Some prefer the 7340 because of the tiny holes. I actually prefer the 7310. But for me there is no difference in usage or outcome.<br />I was a disposable razor person for decades. Lots of money spent on all brands of disposable razors. It seems that the disposable razors have gotten cheaper duller blades over the decades requiring the purchase of more and more disposable razors.<br />Note: every persons skin is different. Hair is different.<br />I have very thick facial hair. The (any) disposable - and I tried them all - would only last at most 2 days/two shaves. Costs add up quickly.<br />The Philips Norelco 7310 is a cordless shaver. The charge stays strong for me for days. No issues with battery or charge.<br />The Philips Norelco 7310 and 7340 appear more sturdy then the newer replacement Norelco models.<br />All are Made in China. The days of Made in USA are few now.<br />I have read all of the negative one star comments. I guess some folks are not satisfied for whatever reason.<br />These models 7310 and 7340 are discontinued. But still available. I have read that the newer models are not as good.<br />Both the 7310 and the 7340 have washable heads. Which I do frequently for my own satisfaction.<br />These cordless shavers are the best for my usage. I have purchased one spare for future use.<br />I have never had any issues of chaffing skin or such. Always a smooth shave.<br />Both my 7310 and my 7340 are over one year old and still operating perfectly.<br />Highly recommended.
  767. Gave this shaver to my father-in-law for Father's Day. He was in a rehab facility at the time. Here it is 6 months later & he's still raving about it..

  773. I've had this razor for about 6 years, and it still works as it should, the rechargeable batteries still hold a charge (but not as well as it used to), and, surprisingly, I'm still using the original razor heads, but they are past due for a replacement.<br /><br />How does it compare to a regular (disposable) razor? Well, when I'm in a hurry and don't have much time to shave, I use this electric razor; but only as long as my beard stubble is very short, if I had shaved the day before. If my stubble is more than two days old, this razor can't handle it. It tends to start pulling my beard hair instead of cutting it. OUCH! Also, it does NOT cut as close as a blade, not close.<br /><br />Normally I use a blade to shave with because I want a good close shave, and only use this electric razor for an occasional quick shave/touch-up. In my many years of experience, no electric razor can shave a close as a blade. That's all there is to it.
  774. I used this for a few years longing to get something different. It's cheap but you pay for that day after endless shaving day. Save yourself some grief and buy the expensive wet-and-dry norelco variety. You'll be much happier.

  776. This razor is much quieter than the Braun that I replaced. With that razor, everyone knew when I was shaving. Now no one else can even hear it.
