  780. I bought this razor to replace a 6 month old Architec. The architec was one of the poorest performing razors I have ever owned in over 40 years. So I bought this razor with very low expectations. I was totally amazed by the 7310. It is so quiet the bathroom fan almost drowns it out, but the cut is AMAZING. I have had seven Norelco shavers so when I tried this unit, I couldn't believe it. I can shave in 30 seconds instead of the 7 minutes for the Architec. It is close, comfortable, no heavy pressing to get a close cut, and best of all is the price. The whole new shaver was cheaper than buying just the replacement head for the Architec. And the 7310 is EASY to clean. Flip the head, flush under running water for a few seconds, and let it dry. No static whisker cling like the Architec. I'd give it six stars if I could. Thanks, Norelco
  781. I bought it for my son after fing replacement blades for his older Norelco had gotten to the pain in the butt, level.   782. This mens razor is light weight and easy to use. Gives a close shave and should give long service.
  783. My last two electric shavers have been from Norelco. The last one required a new blade set, and a new battery. It just isn't economical when you can just buy a new shaver for less than that, so I settled for this Norelco 7310XL. The more expensive ones didn't seem to have many more features that justified the extra cost. I've been using this for about two months now, and I can't believe that I can get this close of a shave with an electric!! It definitely surpasses my last two models in that respect. It's also handy to be able to rinse the head with tap water, as opposed to having to buy a special razor head cleaner. With the past Norelcos that I've used, if the battery goes dead in the middle of a shave, I had to plug it in and wait a while before I could resume shaving. With the 7310XL, if the battery goes dead, I just plug it in and keep going. That's a good thing because that brings me to one minor complaint. This shaver only lasts just over one week on a charge. In it's prime, my last one went about 2-3 weeks before needing a charge. The only other complaint is that it doesn't include a carrying pouch as the ones in the past have included.<br /><br />Overall, I'm very satisfied with the purchase of this fine electric razor.

  788. I've been using Norelco shavers for over 15 years - some were in the $150 range, none were as inexpensive as this one, and none shaved as well as this one does. I've been using it now for over a month and it's been providing the closest shave I've had in years with an electric. Seems to keep a nice charge as well. The one con I have is with the positioning of the side-burn trimmer. My last two Norelco shavers had pop-open trimmers that stayed in place as you trimmed sideburns or trimmed beard hair before a shave. This one has a tendency to close shut nearly every time I use the trimmer. I suppose you could try to use it upside down, but it's ergonomically awkward and doesn't provide a good trim at that angle. The trimmer is basically useless. Put that aside and this would be a 5 star shaver all the way. Still, for the price, it's worth forgoing the trimmer and using a separate one.
  789. I've been using blades for years, but figured an electric would be cheaper in the long run. I feel I miss a lot more spots with the electric and it takes longer. It IS a good backup though and does give a good, clean shave for when you're on the run or out of blades.

  791. This electric razor was a huge disappointment. I ordered it based on the positive reviews here, after my old, very satisfactory (obsolete) Norelco shot craps. Unfortunately, I found that this particular Norelco didn't work for me. Right out of the box, it felt very lightweight and unsubstantial in my hand -- the first clue that it wasn't up for the job. The trimmer is a joke compared to the one on my old Norelco and sometimes slams shut while in use. This razor requires many passes to remove hair, which is quite tedious and time consuming. And no matter how many times and in how many directions I go over a particular patch of skin -- side to side, up and down, catty-corner and rotating -- it still sometimes leaves unsightly rogue hairs. Because so many passes are required, this lame razor leaves irritated, rough and (sometimes) painfully abraded skin in its wake. Furthermore, it doesn't whack the hair as short as it should, resulting in two shaves a day rather than a single morning shave. I have a light beard. It shouldn't be this hard to get a smooth shave. This thing is junk. Don't waste your money.
  792. Have seen this razor for $66 elsewhere plus shipping. I paid $29.99 plus tax, free shipping. Close shave. Being able to rinse clean saves lots of time. Have now bought another one as gift.
  793. As I stroke my one day old stubbles, I said, man this was a great shave. No missed hairs, every hair growing in as per usual--no mess no fuss no drama. The regular shave, however, is superbly stellar. After using two different foil Braun shavers, I would say no way I can vanquish this beast in one or two passes. And yet, this shaver showed me the error of my presumptions. Outstanding purchase, no regrets. This is a man's shaver.
  794. I have used Norelco electric shavers for over 40 years - guess I'm stuck in a rut :>). I am pleased after about 2 months of use . . . it is lighter and quieter and shaves closer than the dull blades of the last Norelco, perhaps better than the last new blades I used. If it is still doing great a year from now, I will be even more pleased! It does not hold a charge as long as the last one, but I get 2 - 3 weeks with this one, about a month on the older model. One thing to be wary of . . . when I purchased this one from Amazon, they had two with similar model numbers. One was about twice as expensive, but I think it is the same as this one. Don't buy the more expensive one unless you are sure it is different and has features making it worth the money.

  817. It shaves pretty closely and it's quiet. My only real complaint is that you can't just leave it plugged in like you can with most rechargeable razors. According to the instructions, leaving it plugged in will kill the battery over time. You are supposed to wait until the battery is almost dead before you charge it again. Sort of a pain. My old one I just kept plugged in all of the time and took the cord out of the end when I shaved. When I was done, I just plugged it back in to keep it charged. You can't keep this one charged. Charge it, use it 'til it's dying, then charge it again. What a pain! (You can use it as a corded razor when it starts dying, or even every time you shave, but you have to unplug it afterwards or it will kill the charging capabilities. I didn't think batteries these days still developed \\"memory\\", but I guess because it's so inexpensive, it uses a cheap battery.) I wouldn't recommend this to anyone who can afford a better one. I wouldn't have bought this had I known that I couldn't keep it plugged all the time.<br /><br />Also, if you have a sensitive neck area, stay away from this shaver. It will give you a lot of razor burn and unfortunately will not work in just one pass.<br /><br />All in all, worth the price, but I would suggest using disposables for a little while longer while you save up to get a better one.

  842. This razor works great. It cuts close, and the charge lasts for a long time. It is easy to use, and the charge lasts a long time. The shaver also has a pop-up trimmer in the back. It comes with a small two-sided brush for cleaning, and a plastic cover to keep dust out of the heads.<br /><br />The shaver uses a special patented technology to cut hair closer to the skin. The process involves two blades; one pulls the hair partly out of the skin, and the other cuts it. Once it's cut, the hair retreats back into the skin, resulting in a nice close shave. According to the manufacturer, your skin needs to adjust to the new shaving style for the shaver to work the way it's supposed to. This could take a week or two (depending on how often you shave).<br /><br />As with many razors, the batteries are not removable; you charge it by plugging it into either a 100V or 240V AC outlet using the included adapter. Don't charge the razor if the indoor temperature is above 95°, or the lifetime of the batteries could be reduced.<br /><br />To clean the shaver, the instruction manual says to turn it off and unplug it, and then open the top and rinse inside the hair chamber with hot water, as well as both sides of the heads. Leave it open to dry. If you don't feel comfortable using water, use the included brush. The manual says to clean the pop-up trimmer after each use, using the brush (instead of water).
  843. Works OK for a quick shave. Cant beat shaving cream and razor
  844. I have purchased three of these shavers (for me and my two teenage sons) because they work great. Quick, clean shaves, and very easy to clean (just rinse under water).
  845. Good, economical cordless shaver. Very quiet. Lasts over 2 weeks of 5 min daily use on a charge. Overnight charge time not a problem. There is *no* indication the state of charge on the battery - the razor just stops. One more note, the charging indicator seems backward in design to me. It glows constantly while charging (around 8 hours). When it is done charging then it blinks until you unplug the charger.
  846. This is really a good razor at a very good price. It gives a very close smooth shave. The razor is light and flexible. The battery seems to maintain a very long charge and powers the cutting heads with no detectable slowing.
  847. The systems works great, the battery last a lot. If you are looking for a good shaving machine and don't want to spend too much this is what you need.

It was a great price, and it came quickly after I ordered it.
  849. Shaves the neck hair very well. The cost of buying new blades and a new battery is more than purchasing this shaver. I get an excellent shave with this shaver. Very pleased with the price and the performance.
  850. You don't need an expensive shaver to do the job. This shaver does just that. Gives a nice close shave for the price.
  851. I shave my head and for years used a Braun foil shaver. I thought it worked well but then it died. Shopped around and the prices for Braun scared me. Decided to try a Norelco 7310XL rotary shaver although I had never used a rotary. Absolutely incredible. Much closer and much faster. Strongly recommend it to \\"head shavers\\".
  852. Bought this as a gift for my husband. It is well made and gets the job done. He is very satisified with this razor. It shaves just as well as a manual razor. You can't beat it for the price.
  853. While this razor does take HQ8 replacement blades & combs. The included blades can be best compared to the economy ink cartridges that come with some printers. They're similar to the HQ55 blades, but have the HQ8 \\"hub\\" so they work with this razor. The combs are very much similar to the HQ55 combs. I'm a bit disappointed in this situation, but I decided not to return the razor due to the low cost of this model. I'll probably just get replacement blades sooner than recommended.
  854. dry and wet shave, washable, soft shave, what more could you ask for? rechargeable battery life is sooo long, with first charge i've been using for 2 months to now, fast shave
  855. I bought this for my dad for x-mas. He just told me how much he liked it and this comes from a guy thats been using a razor for the last 60 years
  856. I loved the machine, it has a wonderful performance, it makes shaving an easy job. The price is very well suitable.<br />You might feel a little uncomfortable at the beginning if you have a sensitive skin, but you will get used to it.

One of the worst products i have ever used... its not at all as the ad says, \\" the top of the shaver is to SQUARE so you cant at all get a close shave.\\".. it does cut but you have to go over and over the same areas to get a some what of a clean cut...   860. I unboxed this, let it charge, and woke up the next morning ready to try it out. When I turned it on, the first thing I noticed was that it was a lot quieter than the similar Remington that I bought this to replace. Right then, I expected this shaver to be wimpy and too underpowered for my coarse stubble. However, I have to give it credit--it mowed right through and left me with a nice smooth face. So, not only was it a good buy for the price, but it turns out to be unusually quiet in comparison to what I'm used to.
  861. It works 1-2 weeks on one charge before it slows down. Roughrer on my face than old corded model, but cuts closer. Transformer built into plug makes it bigger than other cordless shavers

  863. For the price this is a good razor but not at all what is needed for around the neck. Better than my last that I got for around 90$
  864. I bought this Phillips Norelco 7310 at Best Buy for $30, even less than was advertised on their web site. Maybe it was the last one in stock and they needed the shelf space. I have been using Norelco rotary shavers for decades, like my Father before me - as they say. I really wanted to get a different brand because it bothers me to no end that the rotary blades cost just a bit less than the whole shaver. Can't anyone make these three little pieces of metal for just a few bucks? I had given up on my old Norelco a few months back, entirley due to dull blades after years of use, and been suffering with all types of disposable razor blades, high end and low and finally gave up an announced to my siblings that anyone wanting to buy me a Christmas present could buy an electric shaver, \\"like the one Dad used to have.\\" Alas, my sister must not have paid attention and she got me a non-rotary. I was going to return it but decided I would give it a chance. What a loss! How does anyone get these shavers with these tiny holes to work? It was not even a good on short hairs and after a few days it was returned to the store. Then, a week of comparing reviews led me to this shaver. I was determined no to pay upwards of a hundred dollars for a shaver. I really lucked out on price.<br /><br />Now, the review. Four stars because I am so happy that right out of the box with a couple of days growth, it shaved really really close - like a new razor. It is as good or better in terms of close shave as any of the other dozen or so I have had in the last three or four decades. It took the full eight hours to charge, but it does work as a corded shaver if you forget to charge up. It lasted around two weeks on that first charge. The one thing that seems improved is the trimmer. I don't use it much, but I recall my other shavers being poor at trimming anything but straight coarse hair. This works well even for a little trim of my head hair, so thumbs up on that performance. Last point is that is was easy to clean and I also like that it is washable though I don't wash it. So, my basic review is that is does everything it is supposed to do and does it well and maintains a charge and is modestly priced. Four stars, and now, why not five?<br /><br />I had to get used to the \\"heft\\" of this shaver. Why complain because it is light you ask? Well, it feels like a cheaper plastic and that gives me concerns about how durable it is. My old ones had a weight that felt substantial in your hand and a thick shell. For all the times I dropped it or missed when throwing it in the suitcase, I never had one of these break on me. In recent years I have found so many products with half the weight and made with less and cheaper materials in China that I now save every receipt because so many once-substantial products now fall apart. Maybe I'll make an addendum to this review after a year of use. Same applies to the length of time the blades last. I am expecting no noticeable deterioration for a year. As an aside, the speed of rotation of the heads seems slower and probably quieter than past experience. I did not notice a slower speed having a negative impact on effectiveness in shaving and I guess it aides battery life, but it took a little getting used to. So, negatives are the \\"Made in China\\" feel and the cost of replacement blades, both of which will take a year to decide if the value is really there.<br /><br />Bottom line is I got a very good product for the price and think it is versatile enough to suit most men.s that is was easy to clean and I also like that it is washable though I don't wash it. So, my basic review is that is does everything it is supposed to do and does it well and maintains a charge and is modestly priced. Four stars, and now, why not five? I had to get used to the \\"heft\\" of this shaver. Why complain because it is light you ask? Well, it feels like a cheaper plastic and that gives me concerns about how durable it is. My old ones had a weight that felt substantial in your hand and a thick shell. For all the times I dropped it or missed when throwing it in the suitcase, I never had one of these break on me. In recent years I have found so many products with half the weight and made with less and cheaper materials in China that I now save every receipt because so many once-substantial products now fall apart. Maybe I'll make an addendum to this review after a year of use. Same applies to the length of time the blades last. I am expecting no noticeable deterioration for a year. As an aside, the speed of rotation of the heads seems slower and probably quieter than past experience. I did not notice a slower speed having a negative impact on effectiveness in shaving and I guess it aides battery life, but it took a little getting used to. So, negatives are the \\"Made in China\\" feel and the cost of replacement blades, both of which will take a year to decide if the value is really there. Bottom line is I got a very good product for the price and think it is versatile enough to suit most men.
  865. I owned a Norelco in the past. I switched to an $80 Panasonic foil shaver because I hated replacing the $30 cutting heads on the Norelco every year. Well, I'm back. The 7310XL is so unbelievably quiet it doesn't even seem like it's cutting anything. The Panasonic would wake the neighbors. I cut down my shaving time 75% from the foil shaver. I don't shave while in the shower or scuba diving. I don't understand the whole electric shaver in the shower thing in the first place. My last Norelco had the pivoting head and some other fancy marketing features. Don't waste your money, this basic model works great. Very pleased.

It hugs my face, and it cleans so very easily! The battery life? I charged it the evening after getting it first, and having used it without really reading about the battery. Well, then I read about trying not to limit the battery life by too greatly reducing its time off the charger. It's now weeks later, and I have not charged it again, or gotten any lower quality shave. I highly endorse this item!

  893. My old Norelco gave up the ghost and although it wasn' perfect it was reasonable. After searching online and reading reviews, I selected this model as being the cheapest equivalent replacement. Most reviews indicated that there is little improvement in value by paying more for higher end Norelco shavers. I had been warned about the external power charger for all new Norelco shavers. It is a cheap nasty frail looking power cord with a power converter box that obscures adjacent electrical outlets. Annoying since I have to unplug something else to recharge this. The head unit is hinged for cleaning instead of detachable like my old unit, so it is far harder to clean the blades under running water. The plastic if possible is even flimsier than my old Norelco. The power switch provides less tactile feedback in operation. The unit is quieter and cleans about the same. The dual green LED's are easier to see. Cosmetically, the unit appears sleek. I will see how long this unit lasts. I just think that electronics in general have gotten cheap and flimsy, hence my comment about discontenting.
  894. this razor outperforms every other shaver i've used, including the high end braun or even the high-end norelco. it gets those pesky neck hairs in a couple passes and provides a closer shave than any other unit i've tried.   897. Bottom Line: a super-close shave, a bargain price, and some mild skin irritation.<br /><br />Detailed Review: First a loooong eight hours to charge. The instructions call for very LIGHT stokes and avoiding pressing the shaver against the skin.<br /><br />Using light strokes, and moving the shaver against the grain of the hair as Philips suggested provided the closest shave of my life...without the nicks, cuts and scrapes of a traditional razor. And, the side burns trimmer works well if you use several light strokes.<br /><br />Philips' instructions say that it takes 21 days for your skin and beard to adjust to the Philips shaver. Presumably, at the end of that 21 day period, the \\"Day One\\" skin irritation is gone or reduced.<br /><br />The Philips is easy to clean. Pop open the head and run hot water into the hair receptacle and across the cutters for a minute. For more extensive cleaning, you must remove each of the three cutting blades...the instructions make that task appear to require an engineering degree...I'll stick with just the hot water rinse.<br /><br />Philips advertises 30 minutes of shaving per charge...it appears mine is providing closer to 45 minutes on a full charge...enough for a week or so of shaving.<br /><br />The store were I bought the Philips had replacement heads \\"on sale\\"...for the same $30 price of a new shaver. The shaver is a bargain at $30...but $30 for the replacement head is silly.
  898. I bought this shaver from Target a year ago for about thirty dollars. It was my second Norelco shaver. My first one was very similar but it could not get wet. My first Norelco shaver lasted 10 years. I had to replace the blades every two years, but after 10 years, the battery was starting to not hold charge for quite as long. Also, this shaver costs only slightly more than buying just the replacement blades, so it is a real bargain. In comparison to the old Norelco, the shave is just as close. On the plus side, it is even quieter than the already quiet old unit, and being able to clean up by rinsing it under the sink is great! In other respects it is just about the same. Great quality at a bargain price. I will never buy another brand. I had tried a Braun before that cost me over a hundred dollars, and I hated it; loud and irritating to the skin. However, for those of you using standard razors, you may or may not like this. Electric razors aren't for everyone. The main thing is, you have to shave with this for two weeks before you decide whether you like it or not. Your face needs time to adjust to the different shaving method. The first time you use an electric razor, it will be irritating. Now, however, I find the Norelco to be very comfortable and less irritating than any razor, including standard razors! This shaver adjusts to the contours of your face, so I have no problem reaching all of my wiskers. The only thing is that although this give you a pretty close shave for an electric razor, it is still not as close as you can get from a standard razor. Pros: 1) comfortable shave 2) reaches all whiskers 3) a single charge lasts for many many shaves 4) charger can be used in other countries (great for travel) 5) quiet and quick 6) cleans up easily, very convenient 7) inexpensive 8) close shave Cons: 1) not as close as a standard razor 2) not for everyone (some people just prefer standard razors) (be sure to use it for 2weeks before passing judgment)

  925. All I can say that this thing is just too great!!!I would recommend this for people who doesn't want to spend much on electric razor & yet expect a great quality . I like this as well because it has universal voltage so if you travel this is a winner!!!
  926. I've used Norelco shavers for 30 plus years. This shaver is excellent & very inexpensive. I recommend it.
  927. Inexpensive and gets the job done. Shaving with this is much faster than with a regular safety razor. The hair trimmer attachment is a little difficult to use though.
  928. Pretty shaver! This is a gift for my father. He is 75 years old. This is the first time he has a electrical shaver, but it is a piece of cake for him to learn how to use this product. The power of the battery lasts very long after each charging. Easy to clean. It's convenient to carry for travel, too.
  929. I had a very similar Norelco model for seven years. Its battery was pretty much toast, so I started looking for another shaver. I'm not brand-loyal but this product had good reviews and a good price so I jumped on the Norelco bandwagon again. This shaver does a pretty decent job, the exception being that the rotary end has a tough time getting all the hairs on my neck without giving me massive razorburn (my old shaver did the same thing). However, I usually just shave using the beard trimmer, so this isn't a major concern. Your mileage may vary; my neck hairs lay pretty close to the skin so that might be the reason. Otherwise I'm satisfied with it, as the beard trimmer leaves a nice stubble after a couple sweeps. The beard trimmer is also ergonomic and not a pain to flip out and use. Pretty good unit, try it if you don't like foil shavers.
  930. without any problem 100 % recommended
  931. I had a medical issue,and due to radiation ,I couldn't use a razor.<br /><br />Brother got me this, cheap and nothing fancy. Damn but does it work, does a wonderful job ,couldn't think anything else could do better. Sometimes I use a razor, but most of the time it is just as easy to use this .<br /><br />Best to use the battery til it is totally drained (others complain about no meter,showing battery level),this makes you use it til it is drained, otherwise you would be charging it when it would not be best to !!! Once every two or three weeks ,is it really that big of an issue.Mine last about three weeks(19+days)between charges.<br /><br />BTW , I was 48 yrs old,this is my first electric razor(purchased Aug 2008) ,I am impressed with this, truly a great value. (10/10/12)It is still going strong with the same blades .
  932. When my more expensive Norelco finally gave out after 7 years, I came to Amazon to check out what others bought. My old Norelco's battery would no longer hold a charge, and using it for a while longer with the cord eventually led to the motor burning out. I decided to get another Norelco, but didn't want to spend as much. After reading the reviews for this shaver, I decided to give it a try. It's not as heavy as my old one, and it does run slower, as some have mentioned, but I find that to be a benefit. The slower speed allows the whiskers to pop up and get cut better. I get a closer shave than with my old shaver. The only negative thing that I can say at this point, after using it for several months, is that it doesn't show the charge left like my old one, and I don't care for the fact that I'm not sure when it's fully charged either. These are minor points though, and so far I am very happy with this purchase.
  933. This is the first electric razor I have used in 45 years. I finally got tired of all the nicks and sores on my face from using a safety razor. The Philips Norelco 7310X shaver is gentle on my skin and gives a much closer shave than I expected. The first battery charge lasted over three weeks. I have no negative remarks to make on this remarkable shaver. I highly recommend it.
  934. Bought this at $30, thought it was a good deal. And only used it a handful of times after got it. It feels like pulling your hair instead of shaving it. I thought Philips always made the good products. Now I know their low end products are no better than cheap no-brand razors.
  935. I didn't want to review this until a few months of use then it kind of broke. Meaning every time we open to clean the heads, all the components inside would just fall apart. We have slowly place them back in place in order to use them, then it's scary because you're placing lose sharp components to your face. I don't even want to use this any more. Before this started occurring, the only issue was that it pulls your hair a little, ouch! Now we have both problems.
  936. I also have the norelco 7340. This shaver the 7310 has a smoother screen consisting of only round holes for hairs and it exhibits less tendency to cause nicks. The 7340 has some rectangular slots to catch the longer hairs easier and the 7340 does shave quicker. However, the 7340 has a much higher chance of cutting top layers of skin (aka nicks) with the larger rectangular slot.<br /><br />The 7310 is my preferred daily shaver.<br /><br />The 7340 is my preferred shaver after 2 or more days without shaving.<br /><br />AFTER 1 YEAR;<br />After 1 year, the two shavers heads became dull and replacement cost of the head almost equals cost of complete razor and heads if on sale.<br /><br />The solution is to revert to the old shaver technology prior to floating heads. Many of us have had the older norelco shavers. I first watched a traveling guy who would go to towns and \\"tune up\\" their old norelco shavers. This consisted of light removing of hairs and a drop of oil along with the most important task of sharpening the heads.<br /><br />How did he do it? Quite simply by pressing the metal screen against a hairless finger tip or palm of this hand. Now you just need to apply this to your shaver. But wait. You have a floating head which prevents the force needed to push metal against metal (screen and rotating shavers)and thus sharpen both.<br /><br />Solution: Remove the plastic that isolates the 3 heads, rinse in water, dry, apply glue of choice (I used cyanoacrylate) and then I waited 30 minutes and reinserted into shaver. This prevents the heads from moving much. Next turn on the shaver and apply finger pressure to one head at a time. After a few minutes all 3 heads are close to as sharp as new and your finished.<br /><br />Life is a risk and your walk may not end as well as mine. Hope you have a good journey and good luck.<br /><br />P.S. If I were a manufacturer of shavers. Putting in floating heads to prevent sharpening while flaunting the virtues of going around facial obstacles with less chance of nicking skin is and was a brilliant idea.
  937. I have just ordered my second 7310, mostly because the battery doesn't hold a charge for more than 3 or 4 days now, but it still shaves as good as ever. And the good part is that, unlike other Norelco shavers I have owned, I can plug it in and continue my shave if it dies during the process. It is slow and I think that that is part of its success in being a close shaver. Like other models of Norelco it lifts the hair and whaches it off at the same time. Being slow it lifts the hair higher for a closer shave. The down side is that it will tend to pull the hair if I go too long between shaves. I usually do a rough cut with another Norelco when I have been remiss in my shaving schedule, and finish the job with the 7310. I love every feature it claims.
  938. The Norelco shaver works well, but can't be used while charging like my old one did. I would not have bought this model without the low price with my credit from Amazon.

The replacement blades recommended by Norelco are almost as expensive as a new shaver, but seem to be of much better quality.

  955. I bought this shaver in part because it is able to run corded if the battery is dead. My previous razor's battery has died and it will not run with the cord plugged-in. Eventually the battery will die on this one too, so it's nice to know it can also serve as a corded razor.<br /><br />When my old razor died, I had first tried the [[ASIN:B005HS9XSK Wahl Triple Play 23 pc Lithium Ion Powered Shaver, Trimmer, Clipper and Detailer]] but found the shaver head to be both too large and contoured poorly--it's concave instead of convex, like the Noreclo--such that it was completely ineffective at shaving my neck and under my chin. I returned it and found this one on sale for $30 after coupon. Some reviewers have said the 7310 has a NiCad battery, whereas others noted that it had a Li-ion battery. Mine came in a box that said \\"Green High Energy LI-ION\\" on the bottom. This probably contributes to the shaver feeling very lightweight. Also, I noticed that while the box said \\"Philips Norelco 7310\\" on it, the actual shaver is a [[ASIN:B00302T2CM Norelco 7315xl]]. The model number is printed on the back of the actual shaver, plus it is black with grey accents instead of black with white accents. As far as I can tell, there is no functional difference between the 7310XL and the 7315XL, and I actually prefer the 7315XL aesthetically.<br /><br />The razor required a couple of hours' initial charging. It's really too bad that the battery indicator flashes to indicate a fully charged battery. It's better than no battery indicator at all, but ideally a razor would tell you when the battery is low and about to need charging. Furthermore, it would be useful if the razor would stop charging automatically once the battery is full to prevent overcharging, as this kills battery life. So far my impression of the shaver is quite good. It shaves close enough, though my face is still getting used to it. I have owned a previous Noreclo with 2 rotary heads as well as a Remington dual foil razor, and I found the foil razor to give a closer shave in fewer passes. And this razor is much larger than either of my old ones, so it takes some maneuvering to get at the neck and under-chin areas. Still, it's actually able to get at those areas, unlike the Wahl. It's very easy to clean, unlike my previous two electric razors. What is perhaps most impressive to me is how quiet this razor is compared to any other electric razor I've owned or used.<br /><br />It came in a box with a power cord with the inverter built into the plug, a small brush, the owner's manual, and a special offer for registering the product online that extends the warranty for 6 months (making it a 2.5 year warranty) as well a 15% off + free shipping coupon for the Philips Online Store. It does not, however, come with a travel case, nor does Philips make one for the 7000 series razors according to their customer service.azor to give a closer shave in fewer passes. And this razor is much larger than either of my old ones, so it takes some maneuvering to get at the neck and under-chin areas. Still, it's actually able to get at those areas, unlike the Wahl. It's very easy to clean, unlike my previous two electric razors. What is perhaps most impressive to me is how quiet this razor is compared to any other electric razor I've owned or used. It came in a box with a power cord with the inverter built into the plug, a small brush, the owner's manual, and a special offer for registering the product online that extends the warranty for 6 months (making it a 2.5 year warranty) as well a 15% off + free shipping coupon for the Philips Online Store. It does not, however, come with a travel case, nor does Philips make one for the 7000 series razors according to their customer service.

  961. My old razor was a 4 year old Norelco that I'd paid almost twice as much for as this razor so I wasn't real optimistic about what I'd get for such a low price. I've had the razor for about a month now and I'm completely satisfied with it. Granted it's a little louder than my more expensive Norelco was, but for the savings it's worth putting up with a little louder motor. The only negative I see on this razor is that you only have about 1 minute from the time you start to notice the razors battery sounds like it's going dead until it stops completely. You are able to finish shaving with it plugged into a wall socket so it's not a major deal as long as you have your charger nearby and have electricity available. I use the razor to shave not only my face, but also my balding old head (it only gets a light workout on tomp of my head) and the battery just ran out today which means it lasted about a month. I'm sure over time the life of the battery will slowly diminish, but that's to be expected. If you're looking for a good, reasonably priced razor then this is one I'd recommend. The small noise level difference between this cheap model and the more expensive models at least for me is not anything that I'd worry about. I highly recommend this product and am very glad that for once I went with the more reasonably priced model instead of the expensive ones. This is one of those rare deals where you actually get more than what you pay for. Try it, you'll like it!
  962. I've tried several different foil shavers and this one was the first 3 head shaver I've ever bought. I don't have a very thick beard at all when it does grow out mind you. I do have fairly sensitive skin and some parts of my skin would get irritated from the foil shavers but I didn't feel it right away. With some of the Braun shavers I could shave 2 times a day, when I get up in the morning and then when I chose to go out at night, without much irritation at all. I would have to pass the shaver over and over around my neck area until it looked as if I actually shaved correctly. This shaver was simply not for me given any of the patterns I shaved in or the time I let the beard grow out. :o(

I've tried electric shavers before and eventually went back to conventional razors because of razor bumps and skin irritation. The lift and cut technology caught my eye and as an Africa American male electric razors usually don't work. So I tried it and it worked.
  1008. Pros: inexpensive, it looks cool. Cons: anything but a close shave, the trimmer is useless, battery life is too short. I only paid $26 for the razor and I still feel like I got ripped off. I should have spent the extra money on a Braun. Live and learn.
  1009. Cut is clean and close. I bought it as a back up razor, but found it so ideal that it became my primary razor. Excellent price.
  1010. The replaced my old electric razor that had a quirky power button and would no longer turn on. This razor works really well and I had no issues with breaking it in or developing any type of rash. I went to a couple of nearby stores and all the razors were 100+ dollars. This is the perfect price and got it in a few days with Amazon prime. I'm not sure why I bother going to the store when it's so much easier just buy on amazon.
  1011. A good convenient alternative to Gillete mach3 during a travel. It's my first time to use electric razor and I feel slight itch after shaving.
  1012. Bought this for the hubby about a month ago. Pretty good, he hasn't had some of the issues mentioned in the reviews like the hair pulling or neck getting torn up. Only reason I gave it 4/5 stars is because it is kind of a flimsy design. Pretty much all plastic. And it is annoying that it doesn't give a low charge indicator. Overall happy with it though, seems like a good deal so far.
  1013. I recently had a corded Norelco shaver, which after a year's use, drove me nuts with the cord always falling out.So I'm trying the 7310XL and so far has been great.
  1014. Made of plastic, light weight, but shaves great for the low cost. no problem throwing away when it no longer shaves clean
  1015. Nothing much to say about this razor. It's quiet, and it shaves my face faster than a disposable AFTER I'm done lathering up. My old one is still ticking after 5 years (through no fault of its own one of the heads is irreparably broken) and I fully expect this new one to last just as long or longer.
  1016. Let me start out by saying that I was really angered by the amount of packaging this shaver came in. It came in a cardboard box, and inside that was a sealed plastic clam-shell that you have to use heavy scissors to cut through, and inside of that there was more plastic and cardboard. One would think that a large, modern company (especially a European company) would be more environmentally conscious. The good news is that the clear plastic that non-food products come packaged in can now be recycled with your cans and bottles in many, if not most, localities. If you buy a product that comes in a bubble glued to a piece of cardboard, you should separate the two and then recycle the plastic with your cans and bottles and the cardboard with your paper and cardboard (the economics of recycling don't allow recyclers to pay someone to separate plastic from cardboard, so you need to do that yourself).<br /><br />I've been using Norelco shavers for 40 years. This shaver is both better and worse than their older shavers. The actual shaving performance is much better. I have an older plug-in Norelco shaver, and, while shaving, I have to rub my face a couple times with a hot washcloth to raise my whiskers. I don't have to raise my whiskers with this new shaver, meaning that I can shave my face dry and get a close shave. In fact, the shave is so close that it leaves my skin a little sore. (In actual practice, I still drag a hot, moist washcloth across my face to make sure all my whiskers are raised.) This shaver is also very quiet, so it doesn't hurt my ears.<br /><br />On the down side, the trimmer doesn't work as well as the plug-in shaver that I already own. It doesn't take hair off as well, and it doesn't stand out at a far enough angle. Also, the shaver part will sometimes pull long hairs instead of cutting them off, and that can be painful. In my opinion, both the trimmer performance and the tendency to pull hairs is due to this being a battery-operated shaver, meaning that the cutters don't have as much power behind them as a plug-in shaver. Plug-in shavers have more robust performance, but they are louder.<br /><br />I can't tell you how many shaves the charge is good for because I shave every 5 days. I get three shaves out a charge, but then I shave much longer than if I were shaving every day. If the shaver loses it charge during a shave, you'll have to plug it in and wait five minutes for it to charge slightly before continuing. You then have to complete your shave with the plug in. One good thing is that Norelco shavers now come with straight cords instead of a coiled cords. The coiled cords were a nuisance.<br /><br />I have some concerns about the on/off button. It is one of those soft, molded plastic buttons that deforms when you push it (instead of a normal mechanical switch). My experience with such buttons is that the plastic eventually fatigues and cracks. I doubt it will last as long as the rest of the shaver lasts.<br /><br />In short: great shaving performance, so-so pop-up trimmer, environmentally unfriendly packaging.
  1017. This is a great razor for the price, close shave and very quiet. the only drawback is there is no battery life indicator
  1018. Decent electric shaver. It shaves slow and I often have to go over the same places more than twice. It shaves my face fine and doesn't cause skin irritation but my neck is another story. Maybe its just my hair type, but this shaver does a horrible job around my adam's apple and jaw line. I keep trying to find better techniques to shave the neck area but I always end up with a rash or ingrown hair. I bought an electric shaver for the convenience but this shaver has been such a hassle that it's made me go back to using a standard razor. I would return it if I hadn't kept it for so long. Oh well, at least $40 isn't much of a loss.

Update - 6 years later - Guess what it still works, and actually it still works, great! The shave heads have fallen out a long time ago so I just use it as a groomer in the shower. Serousily to think this thing is still working 6 years later is pretty crazy. Even the battery holds up very well. Now with that being said I should mention two things. One I only use it for trimming about 2-3 times a month, all in the shower. The second thing is I paid $50 dollars for this 6 years ago, to pay over $100 now is pretty crazy. With that being said I couldn't be happier looking back on what I paid.

  1152. This Norelco razor is a very smooth shaver. I have tried other brands, but came back to the Norelco because the heads are much smoother and they glide across your face much easier than other brands. It is easier to clean than older models. The only complaint I have is that the rechargeable battery does not last very long. To maximize its life and run time, make sure you run it completely down before recharging and then recharge for a full day. Norelco makes more expensive razors with a longer run-time battery, but they cost much more. Overall, this Norelco is a very good value and I recommend it to all those who use electric razors.

  1200. Shaves closely and comfortably after a less a than three-week breakin period. Norelco has been my shaver of choice for over 25 years; the 7310 is the best yet for shaving. It's been running on the initial charge for slightly over a month, but usually I only shave every other day.<br />However, after about a month, the charging/charged light malfunctioned. A call to Phillips/Norelco's support was handled well. After telling the rep what the problem was, he put me on hold for about two minutes, then said a replacement with a return shipping label for returning mine would be sent to me. An e-mail arrived almost immediately confirming this. If I remember correctly, it will be four plus weeks before it arrives. Hopefully, the remaining charge will last that long. If it doesn't, I'll try recharging; just because the indicator doesn't work doesn't mean it isn't charging.<br />Except for the light failing, it's a five-star shaver so far.

  1205. Well I can't complain unlike you all I snatched this puppy up at a garage sell for $8!!!! NEW!!! I know lucky right? Anyway it's much better than my 10 yr old norelco in the 3 heads shaving department, but in the beard trimming department there is something nice about having a duller trimmer. I mean my old one doesn't pull my hairs and I can run it along my beard many times without shaving it to the skin making it easy to shape my beard. THIS one on the other hand look out if your not trying to go full skin you might end up sorry. I highly suggest using a separate beard trimmer if you get this razor. Otherwise this one works great and quiet and goes cordless of course in case you wondered about that. BTW there are NO replacement heads including even the the box might mislead some to believe it. It merely states that you can keep your razors sharp with (BUYING) the replacement heads.But Hey I used my last one for 10 years and still going good with no replacement
